awd_titl_txt: Multiphase Chemistry of Organic Nitrates from Monoterpene Oxidation and Their Role in Aerosol Growth
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Jonathan H. Slade of Purdue University is investigating the processes that affect the lifecycle of organic nitrates that are produced in the atmosphere from organic compounds that are emitted by trees. Organic nitrates serve as an important reservoir and sink for nitrogen oxides, the precursor to tropospheric ozone.  Organic nitrates also impact the formation and fate of particulate matter, which affects human health, cloud formation and Earth's surface temperature. To better understand the role organic nitrates play in air quality and climate, new measurements are being made regarding the uptake, multiphase processing, and fate of organic nitrates that contain reactive functionalities and remain reactive in the particle phase. This effort consists of both laboratory and field work which significantly extends a growing knowledge base of the impact organic nitrates have on the evolution of atmospheric particulate matter, air quality, and climate.

This project focuses on the multiphase chemistry of olefinic organic nitrates and their impact on the formation and fate of organic aerosol in forested environments. The organic nitrate yields from the oxidation of multi-olefinic monoterpenes, and the aerosol uptake kinetics of synthetic multifunctional monoterpene organic nitrates are examined as a function of relative humidity and particle acidity using chemical ionization mass spectrometry (CIMS) coupled with a reaction chamber and aerosol flow reactor. In addition, the hydrolysis rates and subsequent aqueous-phase chemical transformations including oligomerization and sulfonation of these organic nitrates are being evaluated. The production and chemistry of gas- and aerosol-phase terpene nitrates in a forested environment are being investigated during two summer field studies. The research contributes broadly to a fundamental understanding of the factors affecting air quality and climate, with respect to: air pollutants and climate forcers, ozone and particulate matter. This work broadly impacts the education of undergraduate and graduate researchers.  The research is used to develop an annual outreach program aimed at providing local area high school students the experience of conducting research related to atmospheric science, weather, and air quality.

por.por_cntn:
This work was a combined laboratory and field experiment aimed at improving our understanding of the chemical mechanisms for the production of ozone and particulate matter in the atmosphere.  Ozone and particulate matter at the Earth's surface have a significant impact on the human respiratory system.  More specifically, we studied the role of the natural hydrocarbons γ-terpinene and b-ocimene, in limiting the production of ozone, and in contributing to the mass of particulate matter in environments that are forest-impacted.  These two compounds are "terpenes", natural hydrocarbons that are produced and emitted by trees, as part of their natural defense system.  When they enter the atmosphere, the atmosphere's natural oxidizing ("cleaning") mechanisms convert them to products that are then removed from the atmosphere.  We studied two oxidizing agents, OH and NO3, which tend to operate in the daytime, and at night, respectively.  When OH reacts with hydrocarbons such as terpenes, it produces intermediates that then react with nitrogen oxides (NOx), to produce, in the presence of sunlight, ozone.  However, sometimes, when the intermediates react with nitrogen oxides, they combine, to make a new product, organic nitrates (RONO2) that remove NOx from the atmosphere, thereby preventing ozone production.  We measured the yield of organic nitrate production from OH reaction with ocimene, using a 5,500 liter Teflon photochemical reaction chamber, at Purdue University.  We found that for terpenes, the organic nitrate yield is on average, about 30%.  This means that these natural hydrocarbons are quite effective at sequestering nitrogen oxides, which limits ozone production.  That would be a positive result, except that the products also contribute to the production of particulate matter.  We studied the oxidation of terpinene by NO3, and found that the yield of organic nitrates from that reaction is only 14%, a rather surprisingly low yield.  We believe that that results from the fact that NO3 addition to the ring produces an intermediate radical that causes ring opening, and release of NO2, to produce a keto-aldehyde oxidation product.  The latter is a relative volatile compound, and so we also found that the aerosol (particulate matter) yield under ambient conditions was quite low, at about 10%.  We also found that the aerosol yield from OH reaction with ocimene was very low, at <1%, for ambient atmospheric conditions.  As discussed below, this doesn't necessarily mean that these compounds don't contribute to ambient particulate matter, because the products of their oxidation can be further oxidized, multiple times, to ultimately produce products that are very non-volatile, and partition to existing particles in the atmosphere. 

            Our laboratory studies led to the discovery that the gas-phase organic nitrates are quite soluble in particulate matter if that particulate matter contains liquid water.  When they partition into the liquid phase they can hydrolyze (react with water and decompose) to produce an alcohol and the nitrate ion.  The latter compound is very stable and represents a permanent sink for nitrogen oxides.  We measured the hydrolysis rates for the ocimene nitrates, as a function of aerosol pH, and found that for a typical atmospheric liquid water pH, the hydrolysis lifetime is about 50 minutes, very short compared to the lifetime of the particles in the atmosphere.  Thus, most organic nitrates produced in forest-impacted environments will end up in the particle phase, as diols and nitrate ion.  This explains why the apparent contribution of organic nitrates to aerosol mass is low, when in fact it is quite large, hidden by the fact that the organic mass is as a diol, rather than an organic nitrate.

            We also conducted measurements of isoprene nitrates and terpene nitrates in the forest at the University of Michigan Biological Station, in northern Michigan.  During that field campaign, we sampled the aerosol mass, and analyzed the components by MS/MS.  We found that the majority of the organic aerosol mass had many oxygen-containing functional groups, indicating that they are multigenerational products.  The most common function group was OH, consistent with the oxidation starting with OH addition to a double bound, and from organic nitrate hydrolysis.  We also studied the viscosity of the particles at UMBS, and found that they were much more viscous at night, consistent with oligomerization of terpene oxidation products, produced from NO3 reaction with terpenes.

            We conducted several outreach events at Purdue, with high school students and their teachers, to teach them about ozone and aerosol production in the atmosphere, and how they can be controlled.  The students did experiments, and conducted measurements of a variety of atmospheric pollutant concentrations.  We believe that those events taught students that they can master complex concepts, and that it is fun, and effective, to learn by doing.  We believe that we have made a positive impact on the students, some of whom may go on to careers in STEM-related or STEM-dependent fields.
